content.text: Using Fig. 1.2, measure the length \(l\), the width \(w\) and the height \(h\) of the covered stack of slides in centimetres to the nearest millimetre
The student uses a balance to measure the mass \(M\) of the covered stack of slides
Write down the mass \(M\) of the covered slides to the nearest \(0.1 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the glass. Use your results from (a) and (b)(i) and the equation shown
Give the unit for your answer

Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10\%\) of each other
State whether your values of \(N_{1}\) and \(N_{2}\) from (c)(i) and (c)(ii) can be considered equal
Support your statement with a calculation
calculation
statement
Suggest one reason why the estimated values of \(N\) are different
Fig. 1.1 represents a stack of glass microscope slides
A student takes measurements from a stack of glass microscope slides in order to estimate the number of slides in the stack
The sides of the stack have been covered with tape so that the student cannot count the number of slides in the stack
Fig. 1.2 shows side views of the taped stack of slides given to the student. This figure has been drawn at full scale
On Fig. 2.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the \(220\Omega\) resistor
The voltmeter reading is shown in Fig. 2.2
Write down the reading in the top row of Table 2.1 under the heading \(V_{\mathrm{PQ}}\)
The student:
connects a voltmeter to measure the potential difference across the \(220\Omega\) resistor
closes the switch
records the voltmeter reading \(V_{\mathrm{PQ}}\) in the top row of Table 2.1
opens the switch
The student:
* disconnects the voltmeter from points P and Q
* reconnects the voltmeter across the LED between points Q and R
* closes the switch
* records the voltmeter reading \(V_{\mathrm {QR}}\) in the top row of Table 2.1
* opens the switch
Calculate the current \(I\) in the circuit in part (a) using the equation
where \(R = 220\Omega\)
Record your answer in the top row of Table 2.1
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm {LED}}\) of the LED using the equation
Record your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment in the top row of Table 2.1
The student:
* removes the \(220\Omega\) resistor from the circuit and replaces it with a \(330\Omega\) resistor
* reconnects the voltmeter across the resistor between points P and Q
* repeats parts (a) to (c) for the \(330\Omega\) resistor
Use the information in Table 2.1 to calculate the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm {PQ}}\) across the \(330\Omega\) resistor
Show your working and record your answer in Table 2.1
As the resistance between points P and Q changes, the current in the circuit changes

Use your results in Table 2.1 to write a conclusion, stating how the change in current affects the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{QR}}\) across the LED and the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{LED}}\) of the LED
Another student uses a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit
Draw the symbol for a variable resistor
Explain one advantage of using a variable resistor for this purpose rather than the procedure carried out in (a) and (b)
A student measures the resistance of a light-emitting diode (LED) when the current in it changes
The student sets up the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
The student:
switches on the lamp
places the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object (a triangular hole in the card)
adjusts the position of the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen
Measure on Fig. 3.1, to the nearest \(0.1 \text{cm}\), the image distance \(d\) from the centre of the lens to the screen
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to a scale of one-fifth \(\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)\) full size
Calculate the actual image distance \(v\) from the lens and record your value in Table 3.1
State two ways in which the image differs from the object
The magnification \(m\) of the image can be calculated using the equation shown
Use your answer to (a)(ii) to calculate the magnification \(m\) of the image
The diagram in Fig. 3.2 shows the illuminated object and its image drawn full size when \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
The student repeats the procedure in (a)(i) for values of \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 45.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(u = 60.0 \text{cm}\)
The student's results are shown in Table 3.1
Plot a graph of \(\nu /\mathrm{cm}\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(u / \mathrm{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Draw the best-fit curve
Use your graph to find the value of \(\nu\) when \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
Use the values of \(u\) and \(v\) from \((\mathbf{d})\) to calculate the focal length of the lens
State **one** technique you use when doing the experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is as clearly focussed as possible
A student investigates the image formed by a converging lens
The apparatus is set up as shown in Fig. 3.1
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate at which the water cools depends upon the diameter of the water surface exposed to the air
You are provided with:
· a supply of hot water
· a set of glass beakers of different sizes
· a measuring cylinder
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus
In your plan, include:
· any other apparatus needed
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate
· the key variables you will control
· a results table to record your measurements (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
· how you will process your results to reach a conclusion
You may include a labelled diagram if you wish
